conclusion: To find the effective value of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in the coil, we need to follow these steps.
The magnetic flux Î¦ through the coil is given by Î¦ = B â‹… A â‹… cos(Î¸).
B is the magnetic field strength, A is the area of the coil, Î¸ is the angle between the magnetic field and the normal to the coil.
Since the coil is rotating with angular velocity Ï‰, the angle Î¸ changes with time t as Î¸ = Ï‰t.
The area A of the square coil is A = L^2.
The magnetic flux as a function of time is Î¦(t) = B â‹… L^2 â‹… cos(Ï‰t).
The induced EMF ğ“” is given by Faraday's law of induction: ğ“” = -N dÎ¦/dt.
Taking the derivative of Î¦(t) with respect to time gives dÎ¦/dt = -B â‹… L^2 â‹… Ï‰ â‹… sin(Ï‰t).
The induced EMF is ğ“”(t) = N â‹… B â‹… L^2 â‹… Ï‰ â‹… sin(Ï‰t).
The effective value (RMS value) of the induced EMF is given by ğ“”_rms = ğ“”_max/âˆš2.
The maximum value of ğ“”(t) occurs when sin(Ï‰t) = 1, so ğ“”_max = N â‹… B â‹… L^2 â‹… Ï‰.
The effective value of the induced EMF is ğ“”_rms = N â‹… B â‹… L^2 â‹… Ï‰/âˆš2.
The effective value of the induced electromotive force in the coil is ğ“”_rms = N â‹… B â‹… L^2 â‹… Ï‰/âˆš2.
